moves.1. e3 Nc6: Nc6!? I don't actually know why i went for this move.
moves.2. Bc4 e6: I was preparing for a d7-d5 launch on the white bishop.
moves.3. Bb5: Waste of move, why didn't he do that last move?
moves.3... Nge7: Simple defense of knight and now i'm ahead in development.
moves.4. b3: b3!? Normally i would go for g3.
moves.4... d5: Now i have control of most of the center.
moves.5. Bb2: Nice diagonal (b2-f6) for the bishop, targeting my kingside.
moves.5... f6: Blocking threat and now control more of the board.
moves.6. Qh5+: Qh5+ aren't you supposed to keep your queen not attacking in the very beginning? His tactic is a bit to clear 6...g6 7.Bxf6 then a big threat, it was easy to read this.
moves.6... Ng6 7. Nh3: Nh3?! why not Nf3-the normal move, or Bxc6+! 7...bxc6 now doubled up pawns.
moves.7... e5: Cutting out the f4 square for the white knight.
moves.8. O-O: Safely castles, possibly planning a f2-f4 attack.
moves.8... Bd6: Beefing up e5 from the threat.
moves.9. g3: A luft for the king isn't really useful now as there is no threat against it yet. Why not just  play a simple Nc3?
moves.9... O-O: Safely castling, getting out of that pin from the queen. However, with the threat of the Bb2, Nh3 and Qh5 a really good idea? Quite risky i suppose.
moves.10. d3: Maybe preparing for e3-e4 next move...
moves.10... Bxh3: Undeveloped bishop for a developed knight-why not? and moves the queen out the way.
moves.11. Re1: Re1?? I actually can't believe he did this. Well we all do miss a move at least once in our life. However, it does strengthen e3. Remember-TACTICAL VISION!
moves.11... Be6: Safely moving out, to avoid the retake.
moves.12. e4: Challenging black's pawns to a battle!
moves.12... a6: Dxe4 would ruin my pawn center, so i tried to get rid of this Bishop.
moves.13. Bxc6 bxc6: Even though i have doubled pawns, it helps me as it now strengthens d5, so doubled pawns aren't always bad.
moves.14. a4: a4!? i didn't see the point of this move...
moves.14... d4: Now it's a closed pawn center, Now attack on the wings is the way to win this game. I have now a nice pawn chain from h7 to d4.
moves.15. Ba3: Ba3? I wouldn't recommend exchange off bishops when it's a closed pawn center and your a piece down.
moves.15... Qe7 16. Bxd6 cxd6: cxd6?! Qxd6 looks nicer i suppose.
moves.17. Na3 d5 18. exd5 cxd5: Now i have a lovely pawn structure, i told you doubled up pawns aren't bad, i control c4 and e4 with it!
moves.19. Reb1: Reb1!? already thinking of a promotion? we haven't started the battle yet!
moves.19... a5 20. Nb5 Qf7 21. Nd6 Qc7 22. Nf5: Dancing of the knight for a potential mate.
moves.22... Qxc2: Qxc2 now allows me to eat off white's pawns from the base of their triangle.
moves.23. Qf3: Queen is now protecting d3 and targeting f5.
moves.23... Bxf5 24. Rbc1: A zwischenzug is performed by white to get into a nicer position for the rook, an open file.
moves.25. Rcb1: White, might be adding pressure on my queen but nothing good is coming of it.
moves.25... Qxd3: Again white wins ANOTHER piece, and protecting my bishop. You know right i went on to lose this game?
moves.26. Qxd5+: Qxd5! Puts the white queen onto a much nicer square.
moves.29... Rab8: Now trying to lure the white rook away from its square.
moves.30. Rd1: However, whites having none of this and avoids the trap (decoy)
moves.30... Ne7 31. Qe4 Rb4 32. Rc2: Now white tries to get rid of my annoying queen.
moves.32... Qb3: Again a mate threat: 33...Qb1! 34.Rxb1 Rxb1+ 35. Qe1 Rxe1#
moves.33. Rdc1: Now white looks for a potential mate...
moves.33... Bf5: Bf5! skewers the queen and rook on c2! You still know that black went on to lose?
moves.34... Bxc2 35. Qxc2: Qxc2? White should try to avoid an exchange of queens- especially when 10 points down! But white went on to win due to the biggest blunder in my chess life.
moves.35... Qxc2 36. Rxc2 Rxa4: Again, black wins a piece, but goes on to lose.
White rook battles with the knight and now pins it (due to rook on f8).
moves.40... Rc4: Rc4 i wanted to make my h-pawn advance and promote but Kg8! ends the pin.
moves.41. Ra8 a4: Black looks after the pawn. Ok, chess puzzle, White to mate in 2 what is it? GMs would struggle with this, idiots like me would not.
moves.42. Kg2: Kg2, protects white's valuable last pawns. White mates next move... :'(
moves.43. Rxf8#: At 11 points up-this was just humiliating and embarrassing (note this was a 56th GK Tournament Match!), i'm sorry, i'm so upset, i will stop annotating-goodbye. :'(

gameName: Worst chess blunder in my life...
